Posts.Content: Hi. I'm Pete my wife's caregiver. She's 43. Survivor to stage llla primary  IDC triple negative breast cancer 24+ lymph nodes in addition to....... at the same time, stage lla EGFR + primary Non small cell lung cancer.  She's been through alot and back. NED since Nov 2016. I know this topic all too well. We found a lump one inch above my wife's left breast in Jan 2017. To explain I will fast forward and use bullet points. 1. Found lump above left breast in late January 2017 2. Oncologist said " couldn't say what is was " 3. Plastic surgeon said " looks like fatty necrosis " 4. Double mastectomy surgeon " not sure what it is"  offered to order ultrasound. Gee, thank you Doc! 5. 1st Ultrasound Dr said "looks like fatty necrosis 98.9 percent sure" do you still want biopsy?  Absolutely!! 6. March 2017 2nd Ultrasound Dr with the guided needle point biopsy said "looks like fatty necrosis " my wife decided to trust her medical team and agree it's fatty necrosis.  Opted NOT for needle biopsy.  I respect my wife's decisions, I'm still trying everyday to be positive and calm. It's very tough though. 7. Saw the plastic surgeon again, "yeah, yeah still looks like fatty necrosis "  Looks like, looks like, looks like.....how about finding out for sure. I'm sorry for venting on your topic. I'm still having small break downs over this. I hope that you decide to get the biopsy.  To make absolutely sure. I wish my wife would have. Be well moms... Pete.
Posts.Title: Fat Necrosis

Posts.Content: Hi candy I'm  Pete.   My wife was diagnosed with stage llla idc triple negative breast cancer.  24 out of 25 positive lymph nodes.  I'm her caregiver husband. Everyone's cancer diagnosis is different.  Everyone's dealing with cancer is also different.  How you describe your feelings,  I think is absolutely normal to feel this way. Please come here often and let us know how things are going.  Do you have a caregiver to help you through this?
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: My wife sees her oncologist every other 3 weeks for blood work and discussions. My wife sees her oncology nurse practitioner the other 3 weeks for blood work and discussions. The oncologist is very busy, thats why there is a flip flop every 3 weeks.  My wife also goes in for port flushes.  My wifes sees both her surgeons  (breast and lung) every 6 months. My wife sees her breast reconstruction surgeon every 4 months. I hope my post helped you commett. Be well. Pete.
Posts.Title: Post chemotherapy seeing the onocologist

Posts.Content: In Nov 2014 my wife was diagnosed IDC with a grade 3 tumor, triple negative breast cancer, stage IIIA, 25 pos+ lymph nodes. Double mastectomy, 4 rounds of chemotherapy (Adriamycin and Cytoxan), 30+ radiation.  In Oct 2016 she was NED.  In Aug 2017 distant recurrence of breast cancer.  She's still...a wife that's living a wife that's fighting a wife that's loving
Posts.Title: RE: invasive ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: On Dec 01, 2017 9:19 PM NancyMcLean wrote: What does the HER 2 mean, mine was negative. Her2 is a (gene) inside breast cells that says how a healthy cell will grow.  It means: If there is HER2 present in your breast cancer... ...its Her2 positive  If there is Not Her2 present in your breast cancer........ its Her2 negative Just a visual example below: When I think of Pac-Man the arcade game, it's easier for me to understand.  Pac-Man is the breast cancer cell The Turned Blue Ghosts are the healthy Her2 breast cells ---------------------------------------------------------------- Pac-Man(cancer) eats the Turned  Blue Ghosts(healthy cells) The doctor takes one of the Pac-Man out of the body and  looks at Pac-Man's stomach. (Biopsy/pathology)  If Her2 is found in the Pac-Man's stomach it's Her2 positive  If Her2 is NOT found in the Pac-Man's stomach it (could be) HER2 negative. I only say (could be) because the doctor may not have looked close enough or used the best test for the pathology and/ or group choice.   Just a visual example below: Kinda like "maybe" there is a needle in a hay stack. You look thoroughly through the whole hay stack with your hands/fingers test and didn't find any needle. But....you use a magnet (the correct test) and boom.... you find the needle in seconds. Needle found using the magnet is Her2 positive  NO needle found using the magnet is "definitely" Her2 negative.  ---------------------------------------------------------------- Finding out the Her2 status of breast cancer cells will make best prognosis possible including a cure. Your doctor will use the best possible treatment that only fights Her2 negative cancer.  ------------------------------------------------------------------ My wife is Her2 Negative.

Posts.Title: RE: invasive ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: NED= No Evidence of Disease  My wife's treatment for her IDC had to be put on hold for months. She was diagnosed IDC in Nov 2014 Her first round of adjuvant  chemotherapy (Adriamycin and Cytoxan) started in April 2015 and ended two months later.  Kind of a big gap between diagnosis and treatment for IDC. But we had a more pressing disease to deal with first.....stopping her Lung cancer that was discovered/diagnosed in Jan 2015.  How long have you been waiting for treatment?
Posts.Title: RE: invasive ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: My wife had grade 3 (poorly differentiated) which meant for her .....fast moving (dividing) cancer cells. When grade 3 cells divide quickly the cancer is at it's peak point of vulnerability. Chemotherapy kills grade 3 cancer cells like using a water hose to put out a little camp fire. Even cells whom like to hide in the far corners of your body that are undetectable from tumor markers in blood tests to ultrasound, CT, and PET scans..... can't survive. If your doctor suspects/his gut is telling him, that even one cancer cell got past your clear margins, that's maybe why he still wants chemotherapy as a (final cleanse) treatment.  ----------------------------------------- These are just my thoughts, I'm in no way shape/form/credited/associated in any medical field or occupation. I'm just a caregiver husband that did alot of research on my eternal enemy.  And for that fact everyone's enemy......
Posts.Title: RE: invasive ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: On Dec 01, 2017 3:34 PM NancyMcLean wrote: Do you think cancer spreads when you have chemo? It has the potential to spread if the wrong/unresponsive chemotherapy is used.  My wife was just taken off of XELODA chemotherapy because cancer continued to grow and spread on her bones.  It happens....... You just hope that the next chemotherapy/treatment will work.  Or the next chemotherapy  Or the next chemotherapy  We just don't ever give up hope.....we keep fighting.
Posts.Title: RE: invasive ductal carcinoma
